video.title: S.T.A.L.K.E.R. 2: Heart of Chornobyl | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text:
S.T.A.L.K.E.R. 2: Heart of Chornobyl
is both an official new instalment in the

S.T.A.L.K.E.R. franchise and
officially the moment I discovered

they&#39;ve changed the English
spelling of Chernobyl, apparently.
Give me a break, guys.

I&#39;m still getting my head around
the Istanbul-Constantinople thing.

It&#39;s been—holy chicken Kievs, Batman—14
sodding years since the last game

in this series; apparently, this
one&#39;s been in development hell

thanks partly to the Ukrainian-Russian war
and partly a general dwindling interest

in watching soggy Eastern European
people getting shot at on nature hikes.

So here&#39;s what you need to
know to catch up: reality
in the nuclear disaster exclusion zone
surrounding Chernobyl went all wibbly wobbly;

a bunch of dirty people in gas
masks went in to try to harness

the power of the wibbly wobbly
and mostly get killed

when the mutated animals show
up to rip out their wibbly wobblies.

They split up into a bunch of factions,
some hostile, some not, and good

fucking luck telling them apart
before you get into shooting range

unless you&#39;ve got x-ray vision and
can see that their identical gas masks

and brown anoraks are full
of knives and loaded guns

instead of individually wrapped
caramels and delighted puppies.

Also, S.T.A.L.K.E.R. has
dots between all the letters,

so I think it&#39;s supposed
to stand for something?

Survivalist Twitchy Assholes
Looting Killed Enemies Regularly?
I&#39;ll work on it.

The plot is you are Skif, generic no-face
first-person war veteran protagonist

man named after his father&#39;s favorite
kind of flat-bottomed oceangoing vessel,

whose apartment gets blown up
by wibbly wobbliness
despite not being in the exclusion zone.

So he decides to rock up to the exclusion
zone and complain to the manager.
That much I understood.

What I understood less was
why his first course of action

upon getting there is to set up
a little electric tripod doodad

at the behest of a random scientist and
watch it go wibbly wobbly three times.

Unless he&#39;s triangulating the
precise location of the manager
he&#39;s going to complain to.

It makes more sense in retrospect
as you go through the plot;

we&#39;re sort of in medias res-ing a bit:
we&#39;re trying to put more wibbly wobblies

into the anomalous artifact
that blew up our house

so that we can sell it for more
and pay for a new kitchen remodel.

Not exactly a heroic motivation,
but it&#39;s enough to get you going

and kick off the routine: explore
the open world, take side gigs, dodge
anomalies and mutants, sell lots of garbage
to merchants, and suck on a few sausages.
Oh, and pick a faction to side with, I suppose.
Not much of interest going on there; it&#39;s

a pretty straight case of fascists
versus nutters, but let&#39;s stop

ignoring the—large animal commonly
associated with Ukraine—in the room.
Bear, perhaps? Yeah, let&#39;s go with bear.

Stanley Tucci&#39;s Agent Likes Karessing
Elderly Relatives 2 is absolutely as janky
as you&#39;ve probably heard.
The previous games were, too, but I suspect
standards have gotten higher in the last 14 years

in indirect proportion to our
standards for political leadership.

But at least in my experience,
the game was only ever
janky and not broken, if you see what I mean.
It only bugged out in fun ways.
Like, there was a spent ammo magazine

mysteriously floating in the air
next to my gun for a while.
But that was almost endearing.
It was like a little companion.

Clippy the ammo clip, popping up to ask
if I need help writing a document.

Oh, and at one point, I was
walking through the wilderness

and there was a fucking mountain
where it shouldn&#39;t have been.
Just sort of sitting there.

But there was no collision attached
to it, so it didn&#39;t stop me phasing

right through and pressing on to
base with a new amusing story

with which to break the ice
with the weapons dealer.

Voice acting in the English dub&#39;s
pretty jank as well; Skif&#39;s accent is on

a bit of a walking tour of Europe with
occasional long holidays in America.

But again, in my personal experience,
none of the jank in Slightly Terrible

Accents Linguists Couldn&#39;t Endure
Repeatedly 2 made the game unplayable.
Just unimmersive.

And there wasn&#39;t much chance of me
getting really into the story anyway,

not when I&#39;m spending most
cutscenes going, &quot;Sorry,

which of the previously established
Eastern European angry

soldier dudes with potatoes for heads
were you, again?&quot; Understanding

of the events of previous games seems
to be important, which I find unfair
given the 14-year gap; it&#39;d be like

only now trying to establish the Hot
Tub Time Machine cinematic universe.

Anyway, here&#39;s the core gameplay
experience: sprint through a grassy meadow

making braying sounds with your lips,
get shot by bandits, die in two hits.

Reload save, walk carefully
through the same grassy meadow,
ambush the bandits, kill them in two hits.
Which is only fair, I suppose.

I did find it very hard to get
through most combat situations

without using enough health syringes
to float my eyeballs on the stuff.

And what is it with this game&#39;s
obsession with bleeding?

I’d get shot, get the bleeding status
effect, duck into cover, apply

a bandage, back into the fray,
shot again, bleeding again.

&quot;Is your objection that being fucking
shot results in lingering, debilitating

injury, Yahtz?&quot; It&#39;s called giving me
an ounce of fucking leeway, asshole.
Anyway, I also get the bleeding effect

every time I accidentally lightly
brush past some barbed wire.

What, is Skif a hemophile who&#39;s
constantly windmilling both arms?

Over time, I learned to
weaponize the jank in my favor.
When being attacked by wild

animals, I&#39;d just jump on top of a car
and bluescreen their tracking senses.

And despite the difficulty, I never
seemed to be low on health items.

Every time my stack got to 30, 40
syringes and bandages

apiece, I&#39;d have to stop at a
merchant and sell half of them, lest

I be waddling around the exclusion zone
with my camo trousers &#39;round my ankles.
So I guess you could call that balance of a kind.

But what ultimately condemns
Stupid Tony Abbott Lingeringly

Kissing Enya&#39;s Rectum 2 is that I find it
rather boring, frankly. I didn’t see

much point in taking side quests &#39;cos
most of them are just &quot;run across a field

and shoot some guys,&quot; and
there&#39;s not much in the way

of RPG-style character development
besides finding better equipment.

There&#39;s even odds an average side job
would use up as much ammo and health
as we&#39;d acquire from doing it, so why bother?

Yes, making your way across dangerous
wilderness can be interesting,

but we have to do it so much
and the scenery changes
so little, it&#39;s easy to get bored and careless

and then blunder straight into an
ambush or a radiation zone

or that one really hard-to-see anomaly
that of course inflicts the bleeding status effect.

Maybe the developers were hemophiles,
in the literal definition of the word.

I think Shania Twain And Linford Christie
Eating Risotto 2 is one of those games
I need to be in the right mood for, y&#39;know?

Like if I want to have a long, meditative
hike across a big world, occasionally

stopping to amuse myself
navigating a combat encounter
while putting on a Bear Grylls voice.

&quot;This mutant bear could be very dangerous
indeed, but if I duck inside this disused

petrol station, I can fuck up
its pathfinding AI and give myself

a much needed opportunity to
relax and drink some piss.&quot;

What, you want more?
Maybe you should demand more.

Maybe poor, elderly Mrs. Jenkins
should have demanded more

when she gave her contact details
to that seemingly innocent

crocheting mailing list and ended up
getting targeted by Cambodian scammers.

Maybe she should have demanded
Incogni’s simple and efficient

all she needed to do was set up and
watch from the dashboard as Incogni

Maybe she should have demanded 60%
off an annual plan and used code
“second wind” on incogni.com/secondwind.
Don’t be like Mrs. Jenkins.

David Hasselhoff is already married,
and he doesn&#39;t even live in Cambodia.
